categories: Expansion for Base-game, Mythology, Nautical, Print & Play, Transportation, Travel
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Pick-up and Deliver
publishers: Österreichisches Spiele Museum e.V., White Castle

name: Hot Air: Solitaire
description:
Players of all ages will enjoy this card/tile game of hot air balloon adventure. Begin at the starting flag and work your way to the finish. With a limited amount of fuel, you must navigate through the sky while avoiding obstacles like birds, lightning, and planes. Pick up bonuses of fuel and repair along the way. Special items like the shield and looking glass may turn up during your journey. Gusts of wind may blow your balloon in all directions, but avoid the obstacles along the ground at all costs.

This print-and-play solo game is free and is small enough to take anywhere. Setup takes less than 1 minute (depending on how fast you can shuffle the tiles) and each game can be played in 3 minutes or less.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Aviation / Flight, Exploration, Print & Play, Transportation, Travel
mechanics: Modular Board, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

name: San Guo Qi
description:
San Ren Xiang Qi is a variant of Xiangqi with a special board for three players.


This game is mentioned in H.J.R. Murray's book "A History of Chess" on pages 133-134. He writes:

There are also enlarged games of chess in China. One of these is the San-kwo-k'i, or Game of the Three Kingdoms, which is described by v. Möllen-dorf. It is supposed to illustrate the war of the Three Kindoms, wei (blue), Shu (red), and Wu (green), A.D. 221-64. I give a diagram of the board; it will be noticed that the lines are not straight throughout, and that each kingdom faces the other two. The pieces consist of the usual 16 with, in addition, 2 new pieces [F] in each of the three armies. These are called: Red, Chuo (fire); Blue , Ch'i (banner); Green, Feng (wind). Their move is an extended Kt's leap, viz. two steps vertically or horizontally and then one diagonally. The game is said to be very complicated and difficult, but is not considered as interesting as the ordinary chess. When one of the Generals, who are named Wei, Shu, and Wu after the names of the three kingdoms, is mated, the player who has mated him removes the King from the board and adds the remainder of his army to his own.

The diagram he mentions can be found in the images section of this games entry page.

name: Skyscrapers
description: Skyscrapers is a solitaire city-building game. The player works to construct the most lucrative combination of commercial and residential zones, by clever movement and inspired planning.

name: Day Trip Rhode Island
description: Players travel throughout the state of Rhode Island, answering trivia questions and collecting four specific postcards before returning to the central post office.
publishers: State of Mind Product Design, Inc.

name: Intervention divine
description:
In this french-only collectible card game, 2 players (one being God, the other one being Satan) are trying to gain control over different populations, using angels or demons, respectively.

While various actions can be undertaken, some including fighting, the core of the game involves trying to seduce humans using either sex, money or power.

This card game is based on a role-playing game called "In Nomine Satanis / Magna Veritas", also by Croc.

The game had an extension (also ccg) called "Cult movies" and a limited edition called "the bible" with all cards with "bords dorés" ( in french)
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Mature / Adult, Religious
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Variable Player Powers

name: Total Axis Pack II
description:
A follow on to Total Axis Pack I: Eastern Front Firestorm.

While the pack features the typical set of German, Russian, American and Minor power forces, Scenarios TAP 21 and 22 feature the Italians vs. the Japanese in Peking and Tientsin China in September 1943.

Scenario pack contents:

12 scenarios - TAP 13-24
Map board - 32x9 hex map named TXP1
Special Rules
Cover/Title sheet
Informational back sheet.


This scenario pack is not a complete game. Beyond Valor and Armies of Oblivion are required to play this games as Total Axis Pack I and geomorphic boards 19, 42, 10 21, 23, 45, 46, 51, and Deluxe A. Ownership of Jatkosota: Finland at War is suggested.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Nineteen
description:
Nineteen is played on a 3×3 hexagonal board. The board is occupied by stones.

On each turn, each player must do one of the following actions:


Remove one stone
Remove two adjacent stones
Remove three stone forming a triangle


The player that removes the last stone loses.

name: Scarabeo Express
description:
"The fun of Scarabeo in twenty minutes!"

Players roll letter dice and place them on a crossword puzzle-like grid to form words and score points. When new words are added to the grid, old words are removed, and black dice are added where words were crossing, thus blocking squares. The first player to reach a predetermined score is the winner.

Contents:
Game Pod
Gameboard
14 Letter Dice
4 Black Dice
One-Minute Timer
Score Pad
Instructions
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Spelling, Tile Placement

name: Spielwerk
description:
The idea for this game is based on Reinhold Wittig's earlier game "Spiel" (#2229). In fact, it contains the same game board, but instead of dice there are building bricks in different sizes, rubber bands and wooden balls.
The original game contains a rule sheet with three games and the encouragement to invent more (much like in "Spiel", for which way over 100 game ideas were submitted by players, about 50 of which were published in a rule booklet).
The game rules supplied include:
- "Das Nest": Two players place their bricks on the game board, trying to build "nests" (holes which only consist of their own color). Then they can put an "egg" (wooden ball) into the nest. The player who placed most eggs at the end of the game, wins.

- "Balance": The game board is placed upright, with one brick under it in one corner. Another brick is placed on top of that corner. All players then take turn placing bricks into the other side of the base, trying to make it topple. The first player to suspect an imbalance can lift the brick on top of the corner. If the board topples, that player wins.

- "Die hängenden Gärten der Semiramis": The game board is turned over. Two rubber bands are stretched over the bottom, then bricks are piled up by the players. Whoever topples the fragile construction, loses.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Action / Dexterity, Game System

name: Kreuzwort-Wirbel
description: Each player get 22 letter-tiles. In a race against time each player forms a crossword puzzle within 5 minutes of time, devided in 9 intersections. Tiles score accouding to their color, more difficult letters score more points.

name: Birkball
description:
Birkball combines, and goes beyond, many of the good qualities of billiards, pinball, and table soccer. It's a great game for connecting with friends, taking a break during the workday, or for parties at home. Two, three, or four people can play simultaneously. It's easy to setup and store. It's for adults, teens, and older children.

There are two teams, one at each end of the table. Play consists of rolling steel balls down steerable chutes across a field into target balls to knock those target balls into the other team's goal area, behind the raised barrier. Goalies launch scored target balls in their goal area resulting in continuous play.

name: Tactical Command
description: Medallion Simulations Tactical Command. Platoon/Company level miniatures rules with miniatures and terrain

name: Delta Force: America's New Heroes
description: Movie tie in game with a basic roll and move design. Features a Chuck Norris cover.

name: Dungeon Express
description:
Dungeon Express is a fast-playing dice game of adventure, exploration, combat and treasure hunting for 1-6 players.

Players roll adventurer dice, attempting to plunder dungeon rooms from a common pool (or steal them from the other players)!

Treasure dice are used to find gold chests (good), potions (useful), poison traps (neither useful nor good).

name: Citi-Block
description:
A supplement for Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader and Judge Dredd The Roleplaying Game that includes the following:

Eight large (297x420mm) full color floorplans
Four full color card stock cutout overlays
A 20 page booklet with rules for designing city blocks and generating Hive World gangs.
Rules for using square grid interior maps with Warhammer 40,000 Rogue Trader.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction

name: Space!
description:
Space! Where nobody can hear you scream.

In Space! players field squadrons of fighters in galactic battle. Players create fleets by stacking sets of 3 squadrons and an element leader and placing them strategically onto the playing field. Reduce your opponent’s military might by destroying his most valuable squadrons while protecting your own. The player who fails to field 3 fleets in a turn loses!

name: Lynx
description: A connection game on a square grid bearing a resemblance to the childhood favorite Dots & Boxes. The goal is to create a solid chain of squares of one's own color connecting two opposite sides. A rule that four lines cannot be drawn out of any single dot prevents deadlocks.
mechanics: Enclosure, Line Drawing, Paper-and-Pencil, Pattern Building

name: Diamantenjagd im Zaubergarten
description:
"Diamond hunt in Magical Garden" In English
The Magic Garden is full of surprises, tricky tasks and puzzles. Players must search the diamonds.


Contents:
1 game board,
1 dice,
4 game figures,
4 cactus figures,
10 diamonds,
60 event cards,
1 game instructions

name: One Banana, Two Banana
description:
From the publisher:

1 banana, 2 banana, 3 & 4, dare you pick up 1 card more?
Turn over banana cards to move your monkey forward. But beware, a swamp card or a banana skin could stop you in your tracks, or even send you back to where you started.

name: Jelly Elephants
description: Fill your bowls with wibbly wobbly jellies before the greedy elephant gobbles them all up! A game of colour matching jellies and bowls with jelly elephants causing jellies to be discarded.

name: Bestia
description:
Bestia (The Beast) appeared in one of the issues of Joker - short magazine for gamers published in late 80's in Poland. However the game was first published in Świat Młodych (Youths' World) - #84/1985. The intro and the rules were exactly the same, only graphics were different.

The mechanics of Bestia resemble popular Battleships in it's basic, being a paper and pencil guessing game played on sets of the same diagrams but that's where the similarities end.

In Bestia one of the player assumes the role of the Beast - the master of a group of mosters lurking in the depths of a dark dungeon.

The other player (or players) lead a small band of adventurers who seek to destroy the monsters and escape the dungeons with their treasures.

Before the actual game all players secretly deploy they units (the mosters and treasure hoards/adventurers). Players in turns try to find and destroy monsters/adventurers, throwing spells and using weapons.
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Paper-and-Pencil, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Plei Me 1965
description:
19 Oct – 26 Nov 1965
A conflict simulation re‐enacting the battles of October and November 1965 in the Central Highlands of VietNam.

"Plei Me 1965" is a two player wargame simulation recreating the actions of the US 1st Cavalry Division (airmobile) in the Pleiku province of South Vietnam during October and November 1965. The NVA B3 Front had an audacious plan to split South Vietnam in two with a strike through the central highlands, if it wasn’t for the intervention of America’s latest formation in airmobile warfare they could have very well succeeded. The Campaign had many varying types of force engagement; sieges, ambushes, running battles and whole unit encirclements.
The simulation is meant to reflect the uncertainties in jungle fighting and the rapidly changing situations involved with airmobile operations.

name: Tisch Federball
description:
Board game badminton!

Features tiny badminton rackets and equally small shuttlecocks. Points are scored when the shuttlecocks land in different holes on your opponent's side of the board.

name: Tatü-Tata Das Feuerwehrspiel
description:
Raise the alarm! The fire brigade has been called out. The fire engine takes them to their next place of action. Who will put out the fire or rescue the kitten in the tree? If you have some skill, a good memory, and a bit of luck you can collect many badges.

Tatü-Tata Das Feuerwehrspiel follows the "sensory" ideas from Haba's Tatü-Tata game, but this is a stand alone game and not an expansion to that one.

The game is packaged in a tin fire truck with rolling wheels that holds all the game pieces but also can be used as a toy on its own.

name: WiseMan: Beyond Luck
description:
Wiseman is a quiz game that eliminates all elements that can be attributed to luck. This means that there are no yes/no questions, no 50/50 questions, no choose the right alternative questions and no dice. The questions are categorized into business; history; geography; sports; beliefs & superstitions; film & books; biology & nature; lifestyle; pop&rock; language; and general knowledge. Each card has three difficulty levels from which the players can choose, the harder the level the more steps the players will advance on the game board.

Content:

1 game board
10 boxes of 100 cards with three difficulty levels
2 boxes of 100 cards with questions on general knowledge
40 game pieces in four different shapes and 10 different colors corresponding to each of the categories
rules

name: Bindle Rails Expansion #3: Eastern Canada, Denver and Rio Grande and Emerald Isle
description:
From the website:

Available Now For Print and Play!

This expansion is now available for Bindle Rails and combines elements from the original Bindle Rails with some of the map building aspects of the first expansion. Resources and Engines are new to the mix. Research the latest locomotive designs to reach deposits of iron ore or carry grain and lumber to build your empire in the Great White North!

Three maps are included with this expansion. Eastern Canada will have you building routes out from Toronto and choosing to cross the border or building west to Thunder Bay for precious iron deposits. If you are looking for a challenge, try the Denver and Rio Grande map - the distance between destinations is great and the terrain is difficult. For a more relaxed railroad experience, try your skill at Ireland where you can build ports and bring in goods from other countries. Build your rails across the island to victory!
In addition to downloading and printing the PDF's, you will need 27 Event Cards from the original Bindle Rails game as well as most of the cubes. If you need to print out cards for the expansion, please refer to the main game page to direct you to the PDF that will allow you to print the cards. The Goal Cards and Manager cards are not used in this variant. Mats are included for tracking your company worth, resource values and engine roster.

Future versions will include upgrades for artwork to mats and rule changes if required.
categories: Card Game, Economic, Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Transportation, Travel
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Stock Holding

name: Overkill
description:
OVERKILL is a fast-paced sci-fi skirmish game set in mankind's unstable and degenerate future, its not quite post-apocalyptic but its only a matter of time!

This is the greatly expanded and more comprehensive second edition of the rules which revolve around an exciting and unpredictable initiative system that leads to incredibly tense and thrilling game-play. What also adds to the fun is the deteriorating turn sequence. Play commences with the turns switching regularly between both sides, but as the battle develops and armies become fully engaged, the turn sequence becomes more and more fickle.

As players would expect, the rules contain details of a large array of weapons, armour and equipment as well as extensive vehicle data and vehicle construction rules. Also included is wide-ranging background material that details the main warring factions and the cities and terrain that they fight over.

OVERKILL
also features a large section on campaign games which deal with army progression, promotion, recruitment, training and experience as well as details on trading, currency, intelligence gathering, propaganda, infiltrating, hiring mercenaries and executions! In addition to this OVERKILL also includes complete rules for solo gaming and seven scenarios for solo games.

At heart, OVERKILL is a fast, simple and exciting rule system backed up by high levels of detail that allows players to expand the game in different and interesting directions. The rules require the clever use of weapons and tactics, command and strategy - and a bit of luck. Victory will go to the skilful player - not just the one with the biggest guns - although there are plenty of them in OVERKILL!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Kabufuda
description:
A deck of cards Used to play Oicho-Kabu. The deck is similar to a Hanafuda deck.
The deck consists of 40 cards numbered 1-10. The object of most Kabufuda games is to get a set total closest to 9.

name: Imperium Galacticum
description:
This print and play card game (or pseudo board game) for two intrepid space explorers and interstellar warlords is all about exploring space, discovering and colonizing alien planets, constructing orbital and planetary structures, researching fantastic technologies as well as about waging war against your opponent and invading his or her planets.

Choose which side you are on: The enterprising and warmongering Humans or the considerate and mysterious Atrayids (not to be confused with Dune’s Atreides).
categories: Card Game, Civilization, Exploration, Fighting, Industry / Manufacturing, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Network and Route Building, Tile Placement

name: Ceylon
description:
Card game for 2-4+ players.
Players are merchants during the Colonial Era shipping goods from the British Ceylon.

Through building plantations, controlling officials, trading and shipping goods (tea, cinnamon, rubber, sugar, indigo and coffee) players score points. The first player to accumulate 100+ points is the winner.

name: Lead Free
description:
The SFSFW Book of Mini-Games.

Is that army still not painted? Don't have time to set up terrain and unpack all the figures? Just feel like a change?

Lead Free provides you with half a dozen original new games, solo and multi-player. taking you from prehistoric times to the far future, by way of Middle Earth.

And not one of them needs any miniatures.

Well, maybe just one little one...
How do I get hold of Lead Free?

Originally a physical publication sent to SFSFW members, Lead Free is now available electronically in PDF format. Society members hace received a free copy and non-members can purchase a copy.

Lead Free contents;

* Witchfinder General: a game of suspicion set during the great European witch crazes of the 16th and 17th centuries.
* Cereal Killer: a game of plague, prevention and cure based around a global cereal crop destroying virus
* Moebius Tube: a game of underground horror trapped on a metro train.
* Earth's Rich Bounty: a game of prehistoric resource management.
* The Thousand ROM Raid: a game of planetary assault using CD-Roms, water pistols and a tennis racket
* 10 Minutes To Mordor: a game of one hobbit's journey to Mount Doom.

Decription from the SFSFW website

name: Ostsee-Törn
description:
"OSTSEETÖRN" is an entertaining and exciting boardgame for the whole sailing family in the western part of baltic sea between Denmark, Germany and Sweden. "Non-sailers" will soon be using the same sailers terms as their sailing players. It gives an insight into the eventful life of sailors. The player who plays tactically with his itinerary plans and exploits the ever-changing winds skillfully has big chances to be the first to regain the home port. The game is also playable in a "race-variant".

Each player receives a yacht, two spinnakers cards and a number of port cards, which depends on the number of game participants. Pulled Harbor charts indicate which ports must be visited in each case. If you want to shorten or lengthen the playing time, one can agree on a larger or smaller number of port cards per person. The "race-variant" is played with only 1 set of port cards, which is valid for all players.

Publiced for Verlaghaus Die Barque
mechanics: Area Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Agoniste
description:
Agoniste is a Pure Card game from Small Box Games.

Agoniste is a quasi-historical game putting players in control of one of four powerful city-states of Ancient Greece. Their goal is to to control the most area of Greece by the end of the game.

Each player has a deck of cards representing different strength armies for their city-state. Additionally, a separate deck of cards represent different areas within the four areas of Greece. Gaining control of new region cards grants players staging grounds for conquest of additional regions.

name: seXXX-O-Fun
description:
From the box:

A new twist to an old game: "Spin the bottle!"

This game can be played by two to six players, sexual orientation is irrelevant. Sexxx-o-fun can be played two different ways but in both instances everyone playing is a winner.

Game#1: Each player gets four right to refuse cards. Use them wisely because as the game progresses you will appreciate them. Spin the arrow and follow the rules included in the game.

Game#2: Each player start with two right to refuse cards. The player spins the arrow and where the arrow stop will indicate the color card she/he has to pick up and the request the player has to perform.

Good luck! and remember with seXXX-O-Fun everybody wins. Actually the one who collects the most refuse cards is the winner.

http://www.sexxxofun.com/index.html
mechanics: Acting, Hand Management, Role Playing, Team-Based Game

name: Rummage
description:
This game is played with some cards (depending on the number of players) from two standard deck of cards.

Each player is dealt 17 cards. Then in turn, they play to the table any card. This continues until someone plays a card that matches the suit of any preceding card. That player wins the trick and puts all the cards from the table, except the last one, to his hand. Then he may make one or more melds. A meld consists of three or more cards of the same rank, the player lays them face down on the table.

The game ends when a player has no card in hand. Players score for the melds they made, the longer the meld is, the more points they receive. Also there are penalty points for cards remaining in hand.

name: K'Dak's Tower of Confusion and Camel Wash
description:
You and your best buddy, Kaka, are two young dudes cruising the back streets of ancient Egypt looking for a cheap double-hump wash and blow dry for your camel, Phredd. Unfortunately, being somewhat shy of means (i.e., broke), you are unable to afford the more reputable establishments. Acting on Kaka’s dubious suggestion, you
head out to the edge of town to a place your mother told you never to go: the old, abandoned tower built by that nutcase, K’Dak. K’Dak was a washout from pyramid building school. He just could never get the pyramid concept straight. Big on the bottom and small on top. How is this hard? Anyway, his attempt at building a small summer
pyramid for the pharaoh ended up as a six-story, straight up and down tower. The pharaoh was not amused and K’Dak was banished from the community in disgrace. That should have been the end of it, but K’Dak had in mind one last futile gesture before he left. He returned to the tower, hid small amounts of gold throughout the structure and then set up a booby trap for anyone who tried to retrieve the gold. However, before he could spread a story of a fabulous treasure residing in his tower, he was run out of town by the authorities and never seen again. The pharaoh intended to condemn the place for demolition, but got distracted with a border war and K’Dak’s tower was largely
forgotten. And now, you and Kaka are heading to this questionable monument on the outside chance that there is something inside that you can barter for a camel makeover.

K’Dak’s Tower of Confusion and Camel Wash is a game of exploration. You and your opponent climb through an abandoned tower hoping to collect enough treasure in order to pay for a bath for Phredd. Things go just fine until one of you reaches the top layer, at which time the tower starts shaking itself apart. You then have to get out before the whole structure collapses on you while still finding enough treasure to make the expedition worthwhile.

name: Twyst
description:
This game is played with a standard deck of cards. Each player is dealt 13 cards, and they simultaneously choose one of them to bid. These decide the contract, if there is a trump and the partnerships also.
Then tricks are played. You must follow suit if you can, and the trick is won by the highest trump (if any) or the highest card in the suit led. The winner of the trick leads the next.
Scores are kept individually and cumulatively, and can fall below zero. Players score depends on the number of tricks won, but basically is positive for winning the contract, negative for losing it, and 0 if they were not involved. (Depending on the bids, 1-4 players can be involved, maybe with different goals.)

name: Drugo: the ultimate drug education game
description:
Each player has a card (similar to bingo) with drug "lifestyle" references
in each space, such as Cocaine, Police department, Illegal, Sedative, etc.
The caller has a stack of cards which he turns over one at a time and reads
the statement on it. Then players must determine what the proper response or
definition is, and place a token on that space.
A winner is determined when a card ihas every spot filled, and checked to be legal.
A variation for scoring is similar to bingo, with many variations, such as 4 corners,
5 in a row, 5 in a diagonal being a winner. There is also a master sheet
which the caller places the cards on when called, so that later when checking
a card, the person can figure out if they got a question wrong.

40 playing cards, 75 calling clues, Drugo Fact Sheet, Directions,
Checking Master Chart, Instruction sheet, and whole lot of pink
markers.

name: War in the Age of Magic
description:
War in the Age of Magic is a set of fantasy wargaming rules based on the "square bashing" grid system pioneered by the "Rules for the Common Man" team. The rules are for 15mm mass battles set in "Dark Ages" mythic lands. Rules include battle lists, victory conditions, magic, monsters and heroic combat. Only 6 sided dice are needed. 46 pages plus 1 quick sheet.

The "square bashing" system, as it has been named, is a departure from normal miniature systems in that it imposes a seven by five square grid over the battlefield. This grid affects movement and combat - doing away with tedious millimeter measurements and allows the player to focus on maneuvering his units and rolling the dice. Squares can be either open (no impediment to movement) or closed (terrain impedes movement).

Equipment needed for the game:

A Table (7' x 5') marked out in a 1 foot grid.
Some pieces of terrain.
An army for each player. Most armies will have ~22 units and 2 generals. Normally, a unit consists of 4 bases, except Character, Artillery, Chariot, Monster consist of 1 base only.
About 15 Dice (Ordinary 6 sided dice)
Some dead body models to represent casualties for the purpose of morale tests.

name: When's in the Bag
description:
Expansion to Who's In The Bag.This times. Teams of players race against the clock to guess the phrase based on a certain time. "Early in the Morning", "When I'm 64", "Pancake Day" etc...

Over 400 phrases
publishers: Paul Lamond Games Ltd, TDC Games, Inc.

name: What's In The Bag
description:
An Expasions to Who's In The Bag
Try to communicate locations such as ‘your trouser pocket ’ and ‘The Kremlin'.

name: Hockey Tivitz
description:
Educational Math board game that uses checkers type movement. The playing pieces called "Tivit"s are 6 sided dice with each side having a symbol and numerical value. The 2 players race to reach the opposite side of the board, forcing them to cross paths and allowing for opportunities to jump over other pieces. Each location at the other side of the arena (board) has a mathematical operation(addition, subtraction, multiplication or division). A players score is the value of their Tivit adjusted for the math operation for each Tivit associated with their final location.

The game includes 30 different paper boards with varying degrees of difficulty. For ages 8 and up.

name: Dig In!
description:
From Designer: Two teams of Dwarves battle it out for control of areas. Players can use special cards that invoke the ability of the gods to attempt to gain the upper hand, but be warned! Each team has a limited supply of troops and once that supply is gone you will have no more reinforcements.

Players will engage each other in skirmish like battles to gain control over 6-7 locations. Locations are worth additional points if controlled by it's matching teams, thus the players must strategically place their units and decide when and where to attack.

To add variety there are are 30+ community cards which each player draws from to attempt to gain an advantage.

During the 8 rounds of the game players will place their units, use power ups, and attack each other. Movement of the units once placed is very limited so it is important to place the units in regard to where the player wants them to end up.

The game comes with 54 cards, instructions, and 2 dice. The game has been designed so that it is not required to reshuffle the cards except between games, ensuring that downtime is at a minimum.

name: Rush Hour U.S.A.: Atlanta Edition
description:
The object of the game is to travel from work to your home neighborhood in Atlanta, collecting three different bartender business cards on the way. Along the way, players must avoid the police (and a potential DUI) and roadblocks created by the Department of Transportation and the City of Atlanta.

The game contains six cars, six matching plastic chips (to mark the home neighbohood), 40 bar break cards, 80 highway risk cards, 80 numbered bartender cards, and two dice.

Published by Aggressive Enterprises, Inc.

(Taken from the enclosed rules sheet).

name: Kawanakajima Gunki
description:
Issue game of Wargame Japanese History #5.

This game covers the very famous fourth Kawanakajima battle in 1561 (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battles_of_Kawanakajima).
A "gunki" is a war story (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunki_monogatari).

This game uses map areas and each player secretly deploy his forces using planning sheets.

Components:

8 page rulebook
80 counters
1 map
2 dice
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Shootin' Baskets
description: A dexterity game in the same vein as Mr. Mouth. A basketball backboard with baskets on both sides is placed in the middle of a turntable. While the backboard spins around, up to four players try to launch balls into the baskets using small catapults. The first player to get all six of their balls into the baskets is the winner.

name: Bible Wars
description:
Designer Notes:

Bible Wars is the first, and best selling, of the "10 Minute War Games" by Warcoach Games. The game gives the players the feel for ancient Biblical combat including differences between cultures and their armies.

The game features the armies of Israel, Egypt, Canaan, Philistine, Babylon, and Assyria. The army decks are sold separately and any army has an equal chance against any other army deck. The difference comes in the players skills in being able to apply his armies strengths against his opponents armies weaknesses and having the right unit mix to do so.

In April 2013, Bible Wars Deluxe was released with new historical units, advanced combat matrix, enhanced graphics, and clarified rules.

name: Toppletree
description:
Toppletree merges the game play of Jenga and Connect Four, while allowing players to create a day-glo sculpture while they play.

To set up, each player takes 18 pieces in a single color – a dozen single pieces and six "double" pieces that fork – and the green base is placed on the table. On a turn, a player adds one of her pieces to the tree by placing it on the nub protruding from the base or the nub on any other piece already attached to the base. A player can use only one hand and cannot support the tree while placing a piece. A player cannot place a double piece on a double piece of her own color, but she may cap an opponent's double piece.

If the tree falls over, the player who added the most recent piece loses. Otherwise, the game ends when a player places four pieces of her color in a row, with this player winning the game.
mechanics: Push Your Luck, Stacking and Balancing, Three Dimensional Movement, Variable Set-up

name: Witchcraft
description:
Story
The Academy of Magic is a place where disciples of magic learn the art of magic.

Recently, mysterious cases have occurred, cases in which students and teachers have been brutally murdered.

These murders correspond to a legend that exists at the Acadamy regarding the conduct of a particular witch. Repeated tragedies at the Acadamy have made people aware that the legend of the existence of the 'Witch of the Acadamy' may indeed be true.

To get rid of the witch, 5 members of academy start the research about the legend of the Witch.

The aim of the members of this group is to find and to get rid of the witch.

By the way, the legend also says that the witch can transform into whomever the witch has killed.

This means there is always a question about, if one of the research members is already a witch.

Humans have their own magic which is different from magic users from far beyond the beginning of the academy. This magic is called "information"...

The frightful magic of the 'Witch of the Academy' can celebrate the murderer as a saint, and can execute a bonny innocent girl as a witch.

About this game

You become one of the 5 possible characters, and by gathering information about the witch, you try to contribute to the research and to become the most reliable character.

Also you must pay attention to the possibilities that one of the members is actually a witch, you may point out a member as a witch.

(In this game, you must discard a field card and take a field card.)

Discarded character card gives you information, while you point out a character as a witch by taking cards.


To tell the truth, there may be no witch amongst the members of the group. However, a character who is pointed out as being the witch may lose the trust of the rest of the players in the game and may be executed.

So it is important to gather information, but at the same time it is important to cast doubt on the other characters by spreading witch rumors, or by trying to avoid being accused of being the witch yourself. The winner is the person who survives the swirling eddy of information and misinformation surrounding the Witch Distrubance.

name: NFL Adrenalyn XL
description:
From the Game's Website:

"NFL Adrenalyn XL by Panini is the all-new trading card game developed to introduce fans to the hobby of card collecting. This easy-to-learn card game captures all the fast-paced excitement of the National Football League and puts you in control. Build your ultimate fantasy team and dominate your opponents with stars like Peyton Manning, Drew Brees, Tim Tebow, Adrian Peterson.

Game Play

Each of the five starters on Offense and Defense can be used only once per set of downs, with the exception of the Quarterback on Offense.

All cards must participate in a play before you can reuse them, with the exception of the quarterback. Even in the event of a first down, cards cannot be reused until each has participated in a play.

Play Calling: Next, the Offense announces their play call: Run or Pass. Run plays use only one starter, while Pass plays involve two starters (Quarterback plus another player).
The Defense is allowed to "boost" the Defense Run or Pass Rating of the selected card by combining that number with the Star Rating of a second card. The Defense may "boost" just ONE play per set of downs.

After the cards have been selected, the Offense and Defense reveal their players and the outcome of the play is determined by the ratings.

Run Plays: Compare the Offense Run Rating and the Defense Run Rating. The difference of the two determines the yardage. For example, if the Offense is 50 and the Defense is 41, the Run gains nine yards. If the defense uses its "boost" on this play and the "boost" rating was six, then the new Defense rating is 47 the rush gains only three yards instead.

Pass Plays: Add the Quarterback Pass Rating and the Pass Rating of the selected player. Take that total, and compare it to the Defense Pass Rating. The difference of the two determines the yardage. For example, if the Quarterback Pass Rating is 30 and the selected Offense Player is also 30, for a total of 60, and the Defense Pass Rating is 50, the Pass gains 10 yards. If the defense uses its "boost" on this play, and the "boost" rating was five, the pass gains five yards instead.

Substitutions: Teams may substitute players only at halftime. However, they can use the same starters throughout the game.

Overtime: If the teams are tied after four quarters, a new coin flip will determine who has the first possession of overtime. The first team to score wins the game."

name: New Characters (fan expansion for Revolution)
description:
In this variant of Revolution, the player with the most meeples can, in a particular area, use the special ability of the character who is presently there.

Expanded by

6 character pieces
5 markers


Published in Spielbox #5/2010
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Political, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Auction/Bidding, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Touchstone
description:
Touchstone combines the violent chaotic action of football with the simple press your luck game-play of blackjack.

Objective:
The objective of Touchstone is to score more points then your opponent. To score a point, the numerical value of a drive must total exactly 21.

Components:
In order to play the game you will need 2 different team decks, a printout of the rules, and a play mat.Each 16 card deck represents a different football team themed after mythic characters and races.

Game-play:
The game-play is fast and simple with each coach simultaneously playing cards into the down positions in order to either score or keep the opponent from scoring. Each card has four values associated with the four down positions. This means that the usefulness of each card varies depending on when it is played. If the coach on offense doesn't score within those four downs then the drive ends and possession switches to the other player. Some cards also have special powers that can be triggered on certain downs that help add flavor to the different teams. An example power is "push" which pushes all the cards back one down position causing all their values to change.

Touchstone was followed by Touchstone: Oubliette.
categories: Card Game, Mythology, Print & Play, Sports

name: Yucatan
description:
Reconstruction of an alleged race game played by the indians in Yucatan, based on an original board. The gameplay is reminiscent of games like Parcheesi or Patolli: players have got to throw pebbles and then use the outcome of the throw to move their stones along a closed track. The goal is to bring their pieces home first - pieces of the opponents can be taken on the way and so get sent back to their home square.

Yucatan, though, has got some interesting additions to make it more tactical than the average race game: it is best played by partnerships of two, who can under certain circumstances move the partner's pieces; a cross within the track allows the pieces to take shortcuts, and similar pieces can be stacked and moved as a unit.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: House2House
description:
The goal of this game is to become familiar with selected scriptures found in Bible Topics for Discussion.

In his turn Publisher (player) should choose one of his Scriptural Questions cards while keeping it hidden from every player in the game and ask the next player in clockwise order the scriptural question.
The responding Publisher can answer the question directly or may request for a Hint.

Publisher may be awarded the score at the top right corner of the Scriptural Questions card, or the score at the bottom left corner of the Scriptural Questions card if a fair knowledge of the scripture is established.
Whenever a responding Publisher fails to get the answer correctly (with/without the hint) within the period of the sand timer, the asking Publisher should read out the correct answer to the rest of the Publishers in the game and then move his Pawn according to the number appearing on the bottom left corner of the Scriptural Questions card in the direction of the arrow on the board.
Winner is the players with the most points.

name: The Farm: Card Game
description:
The Farm is a card game for 2 players whose theme is the administration of farms. The game consists the management of cards that represent planting, machines, animals, seasons, action cards and bonus cards, trying to reach the maximum possible points.

Each player is a farmer, every round he can enter cards planting, machines and animals in their mini-board that represents your farm, with these cards the player produces for scoring.

There are also action cards, which can be used to increase the scores or to harm the farmer competitor, besides the bonus cards, which generate extra points.

The cards representing the 4 seasons can also harm or benefit the 2 farmers.

The strategy is very important in the game because we have to plant, use machines, animals, storing seeds on time, a mistake in planning can delay production and cause the loss of many points.

The mechanics are simple, the cards are inserted into the mini-board are positioned in slots that represent the fields, machines and barns, and every round, depending on its position, generates a number of points that are added to all round to decide the winner.

The game is Print & Play, and have 54 cards.

name: Slammin' Bananas Card Game
description:
Object: To be the first player to get rid of all the cards in your 4 stock piles.
Stock Pile 1 - 1 card face up
Stock Pile 2 - 1 card face down and 1 card face up
Stock Pile 3 - 2 cards face down and 1 card face up
Stock Pile 4 - 3 cards face down and 1 card face up
Stack the rest of the cards face down at the far left of the row. This is the banana pile.

Together, players begin to take the top cards from their banana pile and place it face up in the center
between them. As quickly as possible and at the same time, and using only 1 hand, both players play cards in sequence up or down from their face
up stock piles onto either of the center cards. For example, if one of the center cards is a 4, either a 3 or a 5 can be played on it. Then a 4 or a 6 can be
played on the 5, and so on.
If a player’s banana pile runs out, he takes a center pile (leaving the top card in the center), shuffles it, turns it over to become his banana pile, and
continues playing.
Game End: The first player to play all of his stock pile cards wins.

Components:

52 cards
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Card Game, Children's Game

name: Monopoly: Law Enforcement Edition
description: Edition of Monopoly with a theme of law enforcement. The traditional properties are replaced by locations such as Larceny Lane and Handcuff Highway.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Quest-Chess
description:
Quest Chess was self-published by Donald, in 1974. It is a Chess variant. It consists of an A4 sheet of rules.
(Conquest on the Chess board)
Quest-Chess is played with a standard chess set. The moves of the pieces are the same as in regular Chess. White begins by making any five moves. After that, each player may make up to ten moves per turn. However, no piece may be moved more than once during your turn, unless that piece has first made a capture, or has moved to create a check. You may pass your turn any time after making at least one move.
When you make a capture you must stop and give your opponent the opportunity to capture your piece which made the capture. He has one move in which to do this, but may make this 'recapture' in any way possible. He may also refuse to recapture. Once he has made his recapture (or refused to recapture) you then continue on with the rest of your ten moves, and you may again move that piece which made the capture any time during your turn.
If you make a capture on your last move, your opponent does not get a free recapture, as it is then his turn and he must start counting his moves. If he then captures, you may recapture. If you intend to capture and pass, you must announce your pass when making the capture.
When you put your opponent in check, you must stop and allow him one move to get out of check. He may capture the checking piece, he may interpose, or he may move the king. Once he is out of check, you continue on with the rest of your ten moves, and that piece which moved to create the check may move again. If you check your opponent's king on your last move, it is then his turn and he must count his first move in getting out of check.
Castling is considered a king move. Therefore, if you castle, the king may not move again, but the castled rook may still move.
If you move a pawn two spaces, passing your opponent's pawn on the fifth rank, you must allow him the immediate option to capture 'en passant'. When a pawn is promoted to a major piece, that 'new' piece may move on the same turn.
You may never make a move that exposes your king to check, regardless of whether the checking piece has already moved. If your opponent puts you in check by making a recapture and the only way to get out of check is by moving a piece that you have previously moved on that turn, then this is permissible even if it involve a capture. However, if you have a way of getting out of check by moving a previously unmoved piece, you must take that alternative.
When a player is in check and cannot get out of check in one move, it is checkmate, and the game is over. Sometimes checkmate may occur on a recapture. If ten consecutive turns are made without moving a pawn and without capturing a piece, the game is a draw.

name: Second Kharkov: Strike & Counterstrike, May 1942
description:
Second Kharkov: Strike & Counterstrike, May 1942 (2K for short) is a low-complexity, two-player wargame covering the second battle for that city fought during the early period of World War II’s eastern front. The game begins with the Soviets on the all-out offensive, but its second half is dominated by a German counterattack.

There’s a historical scenario covering the battle as it was fought, plus a what-if scenario that allows players to explore the possibilities inherent in the all-out effort originally proposed to Stalin by Marshal Timoshenko. In it, the Soviet player begins the game with the historical force along with a total of 26 more rifle divisions and tank brigades: everything that was then in the Soviet strategic reserve. Of course, to win that scenario the Soviet player needs to accomplish a lot more than he does in the historical one (capture all three hexes of Kharkov).

Each hex represents five miles (eight km) from side to opposite side. Each game turn represents two days. Each unit of maneuver represents a division or brigade of roughly 2,000 to 14,000 men and 50 to 400 armored fighting vehicles.

Special rules cover such things as: Soviet untried units, initial German unpreparedness, air interdiction, historical and alternative set ups, multi-step German units, sudden death victories, fog of war, German inter-army cooperation, close air support, Soviet armor doctrine, Soviet panic, and much more. The turn sequence is as follows.

I. Soviet Player Turn

A. German Air Interdiction Placement Phase

B. Soviet Movement Phase

C. Soviet Combat Phase

D. German Air Interdiction Removal Phase

II. German Player Turn

A. German Movement or Combat Phase

B. German Combat or Movement Phase

Published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #271 - Nov/Dec 2011.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 2 days
Hex: 5 miles / 8 kilometers
Units: Regiment to Corps

Game Inventory:
One 22 x 34" full color mapsheet
One dual-side printed countersheet (176 5/8" counters)
One 16-page Second Kharkov rulebook (6-pages of marketing)
One Player Aid Card

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Low
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 4-6 Hours
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Zone of Control

name: Colgate Crusaders
description:
Colgate Crusaders is a children's roll and move game published by the company Colgate Palmolive Ltd. in 1983. It was not available for general purchase in stores but rather was obtainable by sending off for it to the company.

The game is a promotional piece designed to advertise the benefits of Colgate toothpaste and encourage good dental hygiene amongst children. It encourages regular brushing and general use of Colgate products and warns against the dangers of too much sugar, fizzy drinks, etc.

The game is set in the fictional Molar System where the players (each playing as one of the game's heroes; Captain Colgate, Blue Minty Kid, Flick Flouride and Mike Molar) are trying to protect the system by keeping it clear of evil villains. They are constantly on patrol battling against the forces of darkness - Sugary Sam, Sweetie Pie, the Gumboot Boys and the Enamel Animal with his servants the Plaque Monsters.

The aim of the game is to be the first to capture 3 Plaque Monsters and return them to your space ship.

name: T'shu-p'u
description:
T'shu-p'u is a Chinese race game dating from the first millennium A.D. It is similar to the Indian games of Chaupur/Chaupar and Pachisi, which also inspired the simplistic Western games Ludo and Parcheesi. Being such an old game, there is no recognisable theme.

Four players compete in two partnership teams to get their pieces from the starting position, around the cross-shaped board, and to the central square. Each player has four pieces, and pieces are moved according to the throws of a four-sided die. It is possible to knock other players' pieces off the track, returning them to the start.

name: Der Räuber Hotzenplotz
description:
Kai Haferkamp's Der Räuber Hotzenplotz is another game based on the Otfried Preußler children's book of the same name.

In this game the Hotzenplotz robbers have stolen a wagon of gold, but thankfully Kasper and Seppl – characters from the story apparently – had rigged this wagon ahead of time by filling it with sand and drilling a hole in the bottom. If the players can trace this sand trail properly, they'll find and capture the robbers.

To set up the game, shuffle the eight forest chips and place them face-down in the box. Shuffle the 24 sand chips, place three of them in a row behind the wagon cart (assembled by the players or their parents), then place the remaining sand chips in the wagon.

On a turn, the active player reveals the last sand chip in the line (unless it's already face-up), then reveals the forest chip that she thinks matches the image on the sand chip. If they match, she claims the sand chip and turns the forest chip face-down again, then the next player takes his turn. If they don't match, she hides the forest chip again, then rolls the die. On a red result, the robbers advance, moving the wagon forward with another sand chip falling through the hole in the wagon and adding to the trail; on a yellow result, the robbers are resting, so the good guys luck out and don't fall further behind.

If the players reach the wagon – that is, if no sand chips lie between the players and the wagon – the robbers are captured and the players collectively win, with the one who collected the most sand chips receiving special commendation. If the last sand chip falls out of the wagon, each player takes one final turn, and if they catch the wagon they win. If not, the robbers escape and the players are run out of town as bungling galoots.

The rules include a few variants to make the game easier or more difficult based on the skill level of the players.

name: My Very First Games: Gitti Giraffe
description:
Gitti Giraffe – as with other titles in HABA's "My Very First Games" series – is a game for small children that's designed to teach them the concept of rules. In this case, players need to choose colors, stack blocks and carefully move a tipsy object across a table.

The components of Gitti Giraffe are two trees, a color die, foliage cards, eight blocks and a giraffe on wheels. To set up the game, place the trees some distance apart, place the foliage cards on the trees, and stack one block on the giraffe's body with its head on top.

On a turn, a player rolls the color die, then uses a block of this color to lengthen the giraffe's neck (taking the head off at first, then replacing it). The player then pushes the giraffe from one tree to another. If no blocks fall, the player receives a foliage card as a reward; if one or more blocks fall, the player gets no reward and the blocks are returned to the pool. When all the foliage cards have been claimed, the player with the most such cards wins.

name: Zitterpartie
description:
A simple dexterity game consisting of a small platform with a stick attached to it, 12 colored gaming pieces, 1 colored die and 5 chits.

The active player holds the stick with the platform in one hand and rolls the die with the other. He then puts one of the gaming pieces (in the color corresponding to the die roll) onto the platform and then passes the resulting "tower" (platform plus gaming piece) on to the next player, who rolls the die, adds another playing piece and passes the tower on. Players who drop one or more gaming pieces take a penalty chit.
When there are no penalty chits left, the player with the fewest chits wins the game.

name: Critical Hit! - Volume 6, No. 4
description:
Volume 6, No. 4 of Critical Hit's ASL magazine, featuring articles and scenarios for Advanced Squad Leader.

The following articles are included:
- The Kursk Blues Cafe (after action report for "Hell's Bridgehead")
- Voyage to Kursk (playtest report for "Hell's Bridgehead")
- Designer's Notes (designer's notes for "Hell's Bridgehead")
- Capturing the Palembang Oilfields (play notes for the included campaign game)
- Solitaire Platoon Leader (solitaire variant rules)
- The Scenarios of CH 6/4 (tactical hints for the scenarios of this magazine)

The following scenarios are included:
CH144: FORT KASSALA; 4 July 1940; Fort Kassala, Monte Mocram Pass, Sudan
CH145: THE IDES OF MARCH; 15 March 1941; Keren, Eritrea
CH146: MESSAGE FOR IKE; 20 January 1943; Near Pont du Fahs, Tunisia
CH147: SEE YA' SAM; 15 April 1945; Near Pillau, East Prussia
CH148: TRAPPED AT AUTHIE; 7 June 1944; Authie, France
CH149: FINAL EMBRACE; 11 June 1944; Rots, France
CH150: PAJARI'S PRIDE; 12 December 1939; Kotisaari Island, Finald
CH151: RACE FOR FREEDOM; 2 October 1939; Kock, Poland
CH152: TIN PAN HILL; 20 June 1942; Sevastopol, Russia
CH153: END OF THE LINE; 10 May 1942; Schwegyin, Burma
CH154: THE CENTRAL RAIL STATION; 14 September 1942; Stalingrad, Soviet Union
CH155: STALKING TIGERS; 18 January 1943; Pont du Fahs, Tunisia
CH156: HILL 150; 16 July 1944; Hill 150 on the northern end of Martinville Ridge, St Lo, France
CH157: ARMORED PROBE; 15 June 1944; Biak, Northwestern New Guinea
CH158: RITE OF PASSAGE; 19 June 1944; Western Ukraine, Soviet Union
CH159: JUST BEFORE BREAKFAST; 11 September 1944; Arnaville, France
CH160: KNIFING THE BODYGUARD; 12 July 1943; Komsomolets State Farm, Soviet Union
TB#9: SHOUT AT THE DEVIL; 18 September 1944; Arnhem, Holland
HB#7: HIGH TIDE; 13 July 1943; North of Hill 226.6, Psel River, Russia
HB#8: THE WOODSMEN; 12 July 1943; Krasny Oktabyr-Kliuchi, Russia
GENESIS#20: SOLDIER OF JERUSALEM; 18 May 1948; Jerusalem, Israel
GENESIS#21: ANTIQUITY; 17 July 1948; Jerusalem, Israel

The following Campaign Games are included:
PL-J1: CAPTURING THE PALEMBANG OILFIELDS; 14 - 15 February 1942; Palembang, Sumatra
HB-CGIII: HELL'S BRIDGEHEAD; 10 - 12 July 1943; Krasny Oktabyr-Kliuchi, Russia
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board

name: Balyna Discbat Cricket
description:
A variation of the classic cricket action game. Small plastic fielders, a mechanism to allow batting, another one to allow bowling, a ball and a field made up of different run areas. It doesn’t get much simpler. Sister product of Balyna Football. Both games were designed to be a competitor to Subbuteo's cricket and football games.
In many ways the game is quite surreal, with the bowler being represented by an aluminim funnel from which the fielding team bowls the ball. The batsman is a counter weight which is held by a piece of cotton by the player. When the ball is bowled, the batsman releases the counter weight and, depending on the angle can play a variety of shots. Great scoreboard too, but completely useless as the scoreboard is metal and the score numbers cardboard. They fall apart far too quickly.

name: Spoing
description:
Spoing is a capture game that can be played with a Series: Shibumi set , as it uses a 4x4 holes board and balls in three colours (white, black and red).

Setup:

Place 8 black balls and 8 white balls according to this figure. Red balls are considered ‘neutral’:

● ● ● ●
● ● ● ●
○ ○ ○ ○
○ ○ ○ ○

Rules:

Two players, White and Black, alternate turns moving a ball of their colour or a neutral ball (red) to jump over a single ball of another colour and land on any ball to capture it. Jumps may be diagonal (as per Checkers) or orthogonal. Players must capture a ball each turn.
The ball landed on is removed and the ball jumped over is converted to the colour that is not the jumper or the jumpee, e.g. if the jumper is a white ball and the jumpee is a black ball then the jumpee gets replaced with a neutral ball (red).

The game ends immediately when a player can't move on their turn (which could happen if there are not three balls in a row somewhere, or if all remaining triples are unusable by the player). The winner is the player with the most balls of their colour on the board.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-a...

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

name: Goal! Game expansion pack: Italian Team
description: This expansion is packaged like a CCG booster. It contains 14 player cards of the Italian football team and one new special tactics card.

name: For the Crown: Cover of Night Expansion Kit 1
description:
This expansion is included in the second edition of the base game.

The war for the crown has not yet ceased ... not even when the sun goes down. While the war rages on during the day, both princes and their armies hope to catch the other unawares under the blanket of darkness, when all is thought to be quiet on the field. However, both sides have come well prepared, going through lengths to recruit special units to surprise their enemy, including a Phantom to cloak itself in the darkness and capture the King and Heirs.

From our popular deck-building game, For the Crown, comes the first expansion, Cover of Night, introducing a new range of units, and an additional Sovereign, to pit against your opponent. Can you strategize your units wisely on the dark battlefield? Find out if you have what it takes to effectively conquer the kingdom under the Cover of Night!

Note, the For the Crown Expansion Kit 1: Cover of Night is not a ‘stand alone’ game. You must own a copy of For the Crown to use this expansion kit.

Game Data:

Complexity: 3 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 2 on a 9 scale
Scale: Each unit represents a brave fighter on the chessboard of battle.

Game Components:

• 42 double-sided 3/4" unit counters
• 40 deck-building cards
• One page full color Rules sheet (Player Aid included)
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Scrabble: Gardening Edition
description:
Publisher Blurb:

Plant some fun and watch it grow with America’s favorite crossword game!
The Gardening Edition of Scrabble is classic Scrabble fun with a Gardening twist! Your score will blossom when you earn bonus points for gardening-related words such as orchid, cedar, topsoil and more! Play Seed Packet cards to double and triple your score with directives for all new custom game play. Show off your green thumb as you strategically spell your way to victory with abbreviations such as ARS (American Rose Society) and names of famous gardens such as Boboli or Exbury. Let the fun bloom!

name: Magic Garden
description:
From the game box:
The princesses set out for a walk in the garden. What beautiful weather today and the flowers smell wonderful! Each princess wants to create the most beautiful bouquet - help a princess and find hidden in the garden wonderful and colorful flowers! The one who first arranges a fragrant, colorful bouquet - wins!

To win the game you need to collect 6 (2 players), 4 (3 players) or 3 (4 players) tokens with flowers on them.
Players move around the game board and trying to collect flower tokens, but not all tokens are good.
Broken branch - move 3 steps to which ever direction
Crown - miss a turn
Rubin heart - miss two turns
Shoe - stay until roll a 3
Roses - move 4 steps in free direction
categories: Children's Game, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Victory Decision: Advanced Wargaming Rules – World War II
description:
Victory Decision: World War II is an action based game that allows you to command a platoon sized force or more in this momentous conflict. It features a unique Leadership-modified alternate unit activation system. The result is a fun and fast paced war game that involves both players almost constantly. These rules cover virtually all aspects of World War II gaming. This rulebook not only provides Scenarios but also Point based Army Lists for late war British, German, Soviet and US forces. All necessary Game Markers are also included within this book.

This rule system is written with individually based 28 or 20mm miniatures in mind. However, scale is not important in "Victory Decision: World War II". As long as your minis are individually based you can use the rules straight away. In fact we found that the weapon ranges look more realistic when using individually based 15mm infantry miniatures. If you want to play with smaller tables, just use centimeters instead of inches and all will be fine.

Using individually based infantry miniatures is the recommended way of playing "Victory Decision: World War II".
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Modular Board, Simulation

name: Fairfax's Revenge: the battle of Langport 1645
description:
Introductory game for the English Civil War series by TCS Games, it is a small print & play wargame on this minor battle from the English Civil War, more a fighting retreat and a sequence of cavalry clashes than a complete battle.

The game features the now classic system from TCS, made of random chit draw leaders activation, based on the quality of the leader himself, that leads to units activation and subsequent movement and combat.
Each leader is rated from 1 to 3 (the higher the better, as he has more chance to be drawn earlier); when his chit is drawn from the pool, the player may move and have combat with all the units under his command. The activation is renewed for each other leader in the pool, except the last one that didn't move on that turn. there are no zone of controls (so movement is very fluid), terrain plays an important effect (as some terrain gives restriction to the attacker and improve the chances of the defender), combat is fast and furious (with advance, retreat and immediate elimination).

There are rules for melee, morale, cavalry charges, artillery and so on, with a very streamlined system that you may read and play in a few minutes.

Very good for introducing new players to the hobby, a sort of SPI quad games revisited and modernized
categories: Civil War, Print & Play, Renaissance, Wargame

name: Monopoly: Halle
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Halle, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Vocabulon Junior
description:
Choose a secret word, and be the first player to collect each of the letters that compose it.

There are 1500 essential words of the French language in this game. Players conquers letters of their secret words by rolling the dice and moving around the board and answering questions, solving puzzles.

The game ends when a player has reconstituted its secret word.

Contents:

1 board,
1 die,
1 hourglass,
4 pawns,
64 letter cards,
264 cards,
puzzles,
a storage rack,
1 insert.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Children's Game, Puzzle, Word Game
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Phantoms of the Ice: Double Trouble & Magician
description:
This is a two card mini expansion consisting of two special players for Phantoms of the Ice which was included in the White Wind newsletter #3 ("Colours of the Wind #3").

Double Trouble is a value "4" forward player. If he scores a goal, it counts as two goals. Although if the other team scores, it also counts double.

Magician is a value "3" forward player. After he is played, you may dictate your opponent the card he has to play for the rest of the match (goalie, defense or forward).

name: Minden Playing Card Cricket Extra Teams
description:
Expansion for Minden Playing Card Cricket. This includes a lot more teams and their stats. Teams represented (and the dates they were first issued:
India - 1989
England II - 1989
New Zealand - 1989
Pakistan - 1989
Post-War England - 1990
Sri Lanka - 1990
South Africa - 1990
Post-War Australia - 1990
Post-War Rest of the World - 1990
Post-War England II - 1991

name: Goblin-Prügelparty
description:
"Goblin-Prügelparty" (Goblin-Beatingparty) is a Fantasy-cardgame in which two players take control of Goblins, kobolds and little devils, who enjoy beating up each other, after they have been summoned by a wizard who was not powerful enough to take control of them.
Players start with 3 cards on their hands and have to decide which cards to play for themselves and which to play for the opponent. Playing cards for the opponent may seem odd, but it is the only way to gain new cards. And since 11 cards in one of the card-rows end the game, you will need some more cards than the 3 you start with if you don't want the game to end early.
Nearly every single one of the 30 cards contains a unique effect, but while some of these effects are executed immediately, others wait for the end of the game before beeing executed. And you can't be completely sure whether they will be in the same position on the same side at that moment.
When the end is declared and the last effects have been executed, it is time to count the strenght and see who has collected the stronger - or more effective - little horde.

name: 20 Questions: American Folklore
description:
This is an educational card game. The stated goal from the publisher is that it is designed to "increase general knowledge and to aid students in becoming 'culturally literate'.

The theme is American Folklore. The game consists of a question tablet and 50 over-sized clue cards, each card representing a different American Folklore character (e.g. Daniel Boone, Paul Bunyan, Wyatt Earp and Rip Van Winkle). Note that some characters are also historical.

On each card is listed 20 questions about that character. Players take turns picking a number, which is tracked via the question tablet, and guessing based on the corresponding clue, until the character is guessed. One point is scored per character guessed correctly.

The rules include variant team scoring rules and ruels that confer bonuses based on how many unused clues remain. The game is also ideal for family game nights, road trips (even for adults!), etc.

name: Tactical Commander: Rules for World War II Skirmish Wargames
description:
These wargame rules are for World War II 1/76th scale battles and skirmishes. They have been formulated over half a dozen years and countless battlefields. They provide for almost every aspect of late World War II battles, with sections on air and naval support, paratroop, glider and beach landings, with a good blend of detail, realism, and playability.

64 pages
categories: Fighting, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame, World War II

name: West Riding Revisited: Free Mergers
description: The small expansion West Riding Revisited: Free Mergers brings more freedom to the compact West Riding Revisited game.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Network and Route Building, Stock Holding

name: Panzer Division Kommandeur 2
description:
It was announced as a remake of "Panzer Division Kommandeur" from Ad-Technos in 1985.

But, it is not a remake. From different designer, with different component, with different combat system, with different scenarios.
Actually, it is just a different game.

This version covers only the Eastern front in 1944. This is another important difference.
One player must play a game as a German Panzer Division Kommandeur. The other player controls the enemy Soviet army leader.

The game uses a random scenario creation system. The map area and each force are determined by dice. The most important point that the goal of each army is given by randomly drawn chits. There are 6 mission chits in the game and each player draw 2 of them secretly. So, each player now know his goal and some information that his opponent might have. The missions, are breakthrough, conquer, defense and so on. Each mission gives each player victory points. At the end of the game, victory points are calculated for each player and compared to determine the winner.

components:
one map, one countersheet, one rulebook

name: Console Romano
description:
In the board game Console Romano, players are Roman citizens who try to expand their power in the city of Rome, while resources are stored in preparation for war with other countries. When war occurs, if you can supply resources for the military services, you receive honor points.

Console Romano has an action-selection system in which players will sometimes become "magistrate" to propose particular political tactics – i.e., actions – to the other players. Whoever with the most honor points wins.

name: Verräter: Söldnervariante
description:
The Verräter Söldnervariante (mercenary variant) was available at Spiel 2003 celebrating the 5 year anniversary of Verräter. The Spiel 2003 edition was printed on a postcard along with advertisements for games by Marcel-André Casasola Merkle: Verräter, Meuterer, Attika, and Attribut. The Söldnervariante was also made available as downloadable file by Lookout Games.

In this variant, the mercenary can be hired when playing conflict cards (Phase 3). The player hiring the mercenary immediately loses 3 victory points but in conflict resolution (Phase 5), the mercenary counts as 5 conflict points.

name: Sweden (fan expansion for Ticket to Ride)
description:
Fan expansion for Ticket to Ride with Swedish Map.

The map can be printed on 10 sheets of A4 paper. The map contains new rules for Harbor and Flight connections. These routes are build like any other route. However, if a harbor or flight route is used, the player immediately loses 10 (harbor) or 20 (flight) points. A rather costly undertaking but it allows you to connect the two destination cities and might help you score additional destination ticket points.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Trains, Transportation, Travel
mechanics: Hand Management, Network and Route Building, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Tom & Tina: Das Tal der Tempel
description: In their second adventure game, Tom & Tina: Das Tal der Tempel, Tom and Tina head to Mexico to meet her uncle, who performs research on ancient temple pyramids. While traveling to the valley of the temples, they run across mounting evidence of a hidden Mayan treasure. Thus, the two of them want to reach Tina's uncle as quickly as possible so that they can begin the search for this treasure, but a few bad guys want to beat them to the find. An exciting race is now underway...

name: Bug in a Rug
description:
From the game box:

"The Game of Rhyme and Reason.
In this hilarious cross between Chinese whispers and drawing charades you start by inventing a rhyme... Anything from "A Rat on a Mat"... to "A Fish on a Dish"... or even "Plaice in Space" The next player then has to draw your rhyme! Moving clockwise, the initial rhyme is hidden and the drawing interpreted as a new rhyme... ... and that is where the fun begins! With everyone drawing and guessing at the same time it's a crazy, frantic, befuddled muddle of a game!"

At the end of a round points are scored for drawing a phrase correctly and for recognising the original rhyme. Several rounds are played and the winner is the first person to score 20 points.
Contents: game pad, pencils, score pad, rules

name: Drive Them Back
description:
Theme:
You and your friends are heroes standing before the vanguard of an invading army. Use your array of very large, sometimes ridiculous, weapons to try to defeat the vanguard.

Goal of the game:
Players try to keep a grid of enemies from growing too large, all while trying to outscore the other players in the end. If the enemy army gets too large, everyone loses!

Gameplay:
Players draw a weapon from the Weapon deck. Weapons have two stats: Damage done and how many times the weapon can be swung. They use this weapon to deal damage to the enemy formation, starting with the front line. Players can keep hitting the same enemy, or proceed to an adjacent enemy. Players keep any enemies they kill. The player can cash in the enemies they've killed to draw from the Epic deck. Epic attacks function the same as a weapon, but are far more powerful.

name: Get to da Choppa!
description:
User summary:

A zombie-themed game for 2 players, where one plays the humans and one the zombies. Each turn, zombie player rolls 4 differently coloured dice (and might reroll some), which decide the possibilities for both players this turn: the higher the roll, the more zombies the players can spawn, and might influence zombie movement, but it is also the different action points for the human player.

Zombies are made up of different coloured cubes which decide their special powers.

Zombies win if they eat everyone. Human player wins if they find 10 fuel for the chopper, and if every human is close enough to get to da choppa! The more survivors, the more points the human player gets, and players are adviced to play one game each side to decide winner.

First self-published edition comes with game board, spinners to keep track of fuel, medkits and chainsaws, five dice, and a variety of cubes.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Variable Player Powers

name: Penny Arcade: The Game – Ultimate PAX Mega-Fan Promo
description: A special Ultimate PAX Mega Fan promo card. Card gives 8 Quarters and 8 Tubes. Card reads, "On Monday, Wednesday, Friday and during PAX, +1 Token, +1 Power. Otherwise +1 Token."
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting

name: Survival Horror Tabletop Game
description:
The outbreak began as a few isolated reports from small towns and truck stops scattered across the nation, dismissed as nonsense by most sane people. As the incidents increased in frequency and severity it soon became clear that they weren’t the ramblings of madmen as initially suspected. But by then it was too late; far, far too late…

Survival Horror Tabletop Game is for 1 or more players and is an exploration/survival game in which tiles are laid to reflect the SHPD precinct house. You need to find specific items to complete the mission and escape, and the zombies spawn as rooms are uncovered and they gain successful spawn points. The zombies are fairly easily picked off to start with, but once they start gaining a hold survival becomes a lot more difficult!

Health and actions are controlled by the same points (so the more health you lose, the less actions you can perform), and there are modifiers for combat/damage etc. You also need to find a way of opening locked and barricaded doors, and working either with or against the other human players. Of course, if you are the zombie player then all you really need to do is to kill all humans...

The 59 page pdf contains all you need to play the Survival Horror Tabletop Game and enter the world of 30mm scale tabletop Modern Horror gaming! Just print, construct and add dice!
categories: Exploration, Horror, Miniatures, Print & Play, Zombies
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board

name: Munchkin Beißt! 'Reißzahn' Booster (Set 2)
description:
This booster contains 20 German-language Munchkin Bites! cards. Seventeen of the cards come from Munchkin Bites! 1 and 2, and they form a rigged demo that can be used to teach the game. The remaining 3 cards are new and there are no corresponding English versions. All 20 cards have a jack-o-lantern as the icon.

The packaging for the booster set is clear plastic, and there is nothing inside but the cards themselves (no rules, etc.). Thus, the name of the booster, 'Reißzahn', comes from the top card that's visible through the packaging. (The full name of the top card is Reißzahnpasta.)
